text.author: Wiktionary
text.title: next
text.summary1: (human1) This dictionary entry for the word 'next' gives its dialectal forms, etymology as a superlative of 'near' from Middle and Old English nexte and nīehsta from Proto-Germanic *nēhwist, its cognates (e.g. Dutch naast, Danish næste), pronunciation /nεkst/ and related synonyms and antonyms, accompanied by usage examples as an adjective, determiner, adverb, preposition and noun.
text.summary2: (claude-3-5-sonnet-20241022) This dictionary entry details the word 'next', tracing its etymology from Middle English 'nexte' and Old English 'nīehsta', providing pronunciations, and defining its usage as an adjective, determiner, adverb, preposition, and noun to indicate proximity in space, time, or sequence.
text.summary3: (gpt4o) This dictionary entry explores the word 'next', detailing alternative forms like 'neest' and 'neist', etymology from Middle English and Proto-Germanic roots, cognates in various languages, pronunciation as /nɛkst/, definitions and usage as an adjective, determiner, adverb, preposition, and noun, along with examples, synonyms, and antonyms.
text.summary4: (Meta-Llama-3-8B-Instruct; postedited) This dictionary entry for the word "next" provides its etymology, synonyms, antonyms, usage examples, and definitions as an adjective, determiner, adverb, preposition, and noun with various senses in time, sequence, and spatial relationships.
text.summary5: (Qwen2.5-3B-Instruct) The document defines and explains the English word "next," providing etymology, pronunciations, definitions, usage examples, and related concepts, while also discussing its comparative forms and obsolete or poetic uses.
